options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: In addition to the weekly virtual seminar, we also had weekly discussion sections over Zoom.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned to critically analyze Lispector's work with the help of Professor Jackson and Gustavo!

I learned a lot about Clarice Lispector's personal life, writing life, and writing style. This course was incredibly engaging and the discussions were always very lively. Lispector's short stories are overflowing with material that could be discussed for hours upon hours. This is great introduction to Clarice Lispector if you've never read her before, and it also offers interesting glimpses of Brazilian culture.

This course was one of my absolute favorites among all courses I've taken at Yale so far. It was so much fun to read all of Clarice Lispector's short stories! I can't wait to read more of her work. Throughout the semester, I developed substantial knowledge of Clarice Lispector's style, important skills in literary analysis and interpretation, and new insight surrounding the powerful connections between literature and philosophy (which Clarice so articulately, and masterfully, plays with).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Some of the strengths of this course was the amazing teaching staff (Gustavo and Professor Jackson were incredible!), the fantastic short stories that we read and the insightful discussions that we had every week as a group over Zoom. I really loved taking a seminar that had graduate students in it, too. It was a first for me but also very exciting to hear what they had to say about the short stories that we read.

I can't think of any weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this course went great in terms of adaptation for a virtual platform. I think our discussions worked really well over Zoom, and it was one of the only courses I took this term where people were clearly engaged (cameras and mics on all of the time)  which can be difficult sometimes when you are taking an online course, but not with this one.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Lispector's work is just amazing.
Yes! Clarice Lispector is amazing writer that everyone should read and discuss. Professor Jackson is a wonderful professor!

This seminar was one of the highlights of my semester. I would certainly recommend it to another student! I think it's a great opportunity to become more familiar with the work of one of the greatest authors that Brazil has ever known. Clarice is just as fascinating as an author as she was as a person. She is the kind of writer that you can't help but be fascinated by. Every literature enthusiast should read at least some of her works!
